Headline: Strategic Disruption & AI Transformation I 30 yrs I C-Suite Mentor | Board & Governance | Fin. Risk & Investment Plan | Growth & Branding | RPA I Adv. Prompt Engg I Writer I Historian I Futurist I MBA (Tech) I MA English
Comment: Ability to stretch into other market segments is a vital clue of how an entrepreneur thinks about an idea, unless the idea is seen as a mode that can widen its value beyond a specific chain, the idea is bound to face headwinds the moment it faces even small impediments - let's take India's Smart Meter market for instance, everybody saw just the macro numbers and rushed to fill the space, what was expected to scale into a mountain is still limping to scale even a mole-hill, out of 250 million smart meters planned not more than 30 million have been installed ! That too over a period of nearly 6-8 yrs! Even today the whole of South India is yet to even start! But, many pitch decks of Smart Meter mfg., business even today consider the whole of India as their TAM ! And except 1 or 2 players not many are even considering stepping out of India ! üôÇ

Headline: Founding Partner at Riceberg Ventures
Comment:
Excellent point, Rishabh. I roll my eyes when they cite the Gartner report for this slide, haha. 

We always ask for bottom-up market sizing, which is also a crucial assignment for our portfolio companies at our accelerator, KickSky Space Lab. 

I find the exercise very exciting when working on a category creator, as you have to build it from the first principle. 

So be assured that if you receive any deck from startups from our ecosystem, their TAM, SAM, and SOM will be bottom-up.  :)

Headline: India‚Äôs MSME Growth Coach | Startup Strategist | 4 MSME Turnarounds ¬∑ 8 Startups Mentored | Author & Creator of the Diamond System‚Ñ¢ | Helping Leaders Engineer Synchronicity
Comment:
Rishab , my 2 cents : 

1) Out of those dozen pitches a day , you might be binning all 

2) If a Founder of a startup or MSME knows how to visualise what you want them to do , they actually shall be on auto pilot , basically you are choosing only those pitches where the opportunity is on verge of scaling up .

3) Such Founders , I work with ,don't need investor to scale up organically , they need investors only for inorganic growth 

I do represent such clients who have answers to all you seek.

4) As a first priority , I look for Customers who are willing to invest into the business and also play customer role and use the products , services thru their own revenue models .

In a way , I do reverse due diligence, am searching for investors who have their feet into the business ground too .
Those who don't think of exit strategy only always .
A Good Founder doesn't need money alone , he actually needs valuable customers more .

Best scenario is to get Customer cum investors for my clients.
2nd priority is pure investors too .
They are equally welcome because we have all you expect .
The bottom up !
Founders who solve real problems are always Bottom Up .
#RDS

Headline: Go-To-Market & Business Development for Agentic AI, Digital Twins & Advanced Analytics | Pharma, Life Sciences, Food & Beverages | MBA from IE Business School
Comment: While I agree that many startup pitches emphasize heavily on market sizing metrics like TAM-SAM-SOM, I believe that they are not entirely useless. Like, for pre-revenue startups, the top-down market sizing can provide a theoretical maximum of the market they are targeting. If the product has already gained traction, then the bottom-up sizing makes complete sense because these startups have a clear understanding of the customer. But for others, a limited pool of early customers might not paint a clear picture, market surveys consume time and money, and startups can also present only a particular set of data, which justifies their agenda.

Headline: ERM & AI Risk Strategy Executive | Expert in Risk Quantification, Modeling & Scenario Intelligence | Creator of Patented RiskXAI Frameworks | Board Advisor I HBR Advisory Council
Comment:
Couldn‚Äôt agree more ‚Äî the TAM‚ÄìSAM‚ÄìSOM slide often feels like a ritual, not a revelation.

The real signal isn‚Äôt in concentric circles. It‚Äôs in customer behavior, usage patterns, and momentum. Bottom-up market sizing doesn‚Äôt just show numbers ‚Äî it shows how you think, how you build, and how you scale.

Founders who start with traction and stretch toward vision give investors a map, not a mirage. It‚Äôs not about how big the market could be ‚Äî it‚Äôs about how far your product can go, based on what it‚Äôs already doing.

Thanks for calling this out. Let‚Äôs make pitch decks smarter, not louder.
